article.description:
Everything went right for Michael Bauer
Friday night. Well, almost everything.
article.headline: Bauer goes 8-for-8 from field, with six 3-pointers
article.linkText: Bauer near perfect as No. 25 Minnesota wins handily
article.story: MINNEAPOLIS (AP) -- Everything went right for Michael Bauer Friday night. Well, almost everything. Bauer was perfect from the field, including six 3-pointers, and scored a career-high 26 points to lead Minnesota (No. 25 ESPN/USA Today) to a 104-66 victory over Fairleigh Dickinson. But he did miss one free throw. ''No one's perfect,'' shrugged Bauer. Bauer was 8-for-8 from the field in just 20 minutes off the bench. Ben Johnson added a season-high 16 points as the Gophers (6-1) reached the 100-point mark for the second time this season. ''We were just making passes to the open guy,'' said Bauer, a junior. ''Everybody was getting their feet under them and hitting the open shots.'' Bauer led all scorers with 14 points in the first half as the Gophers opened up a 50-31 lead. He then hit four 3-pointers in the second half before leaving the game with eight minutes left and the Gophers leading 81-46. Minnesota rebounded from a pair of lackluster outings. The Gophers lost 80-60 at Nebraska on Dec. 8, and they followed that with an 86-84 overtime victory at home Tuesday over Arkansas-Little Rock. But the Gophers worked quickly to forget those games, scoring the game's first seven points and never trailing. For the Gophers, it was a chance to allow some reserves to see significant time. Leading scorer Rick Rickert played just 20 minutes and scored only five points. Only two of the Gophers' starters played more than half the game. ''In order for (reserves) to be able to come off the bench and give you two quality minutes a half in a Big Ten game -- which in some games is vital -- they've gotta have some rhythm,'' said Gophers coach Dan Monson. ''Hopefully this gives them some confidence.'' For the Knights (4-2), it was a chance to get a taste of Big Ten basketball. ''I knew coming in it was going to be a learning experience,'' said Fairleigh Dickinson coach Tom Green. ''I've got a vote in the Top 25 poll. I've been voting them 15 to 20 all year long. I'm going to move them up a bit.'' Fairleigh Dickinson stayed in the game for the first 15 minutes due mainly to 3-pointers. Lionel Bomayako hit three from long range in the game's first eight minutes, keeping the Knights at 17-12 down with 13:05 left in the first half. He led all Knights' scorers with 11 points. Minnesota's Jerry Holman and Bauer each scored four points in a 13-3 run that broke the game open at 30-15 with 8:45 left in the half. But 3-pointers by Mensah Peterson and Gordon Klaiber brought the Knights back to 30-21. Minnesota answered with a nine-point run that included five points by Steve Esselink and was capped by a Holman dunk, and Fairleigh Dickinson (4-2) did not get back within 10 points.
